questions.question: Question 1: Which of the following is false regarding lung cancer?

options.a: It is the most common cancer in Indian men
options.b: Tobacco smoking is the most common cause
options.c: Adenocarcinoma is the most common histologic type
options.d: It is the most common cause of cancer death

questions.explanation:
The most common cancer seen in Indian men is lip and oral cavity cancer, not lung cancer. Most common cancer: • In men globally- Lung cancer • In Indian men- Lip and oral cavity cancer • In women globally- Breast cancer • In Indian women- Breast cancer Tobacco smoking is a primary cause of the development of lung cancer. It increases 10 fold 
greater risk of developing lung cancer compared to those who have never smoked. It is the most common cause of cancer death.

questions.question: Question 2: What is the most common type of lung cancer in light smokers?
questions.explanation:
671 
Sold by @itachibot The most common lung cancer in light smokers (<10 pack-year history) is adenocarcinoma. WHO classification of lung carcinomas: The WHO classification system divides epithelial lung cancers into four major cell types: • Small-cell lung cancer (SCLC) • Non-small-cell lung carcinomas (NSCLCs) • Adenocarcinoma • Squamous cell carcinoma • Large-cell carcinoma Adenocarcinoma is most commonly seen in: • Lifetime non-smokers • Light smokers (<10 pack-years history) • Women • Younger adults (<60 years) In smokers, the most common types are small-cell carcinoma and squamous cell carcinomas.

questions.question:
Question 3: A 60-year-old man with a 35 pack-year history of smoking presented for a routine check-up. 
His brother was diagnosed with lung cancer at a similar age. Which of the following would be 
preferred to screen him for lung cancer?
questions.explanation:
Low-dose CT/ thin-slice spiral chest CT would be preferred to screen him for lung cancer. He 
belongs to the high-risk population to develop lung cancer. The high-risk population is individuals whose age is 60 years and who have a smoking history of 
10 pack-years. Low dose CT scans are shown to detect more lung nodules and cancers than the standard CXR in 
selected high-risk populations. Also, up to 85% of cancers thus detected are classified as stage I. 
Early staged cancers are considered potentially curable with surgical resection. Here, the aim is to reduce medical radiation exposure as much as possible, low dose CT is 
effective in screening for lung cancer, and is thus preferred.

questions.question: Question 4: Which of the following is false about hypertrophic osteoarthropathy?

options.a: Platelets have a role in the development of HOA
options.c: HOA is commonly associated with lung malignancies
options.d: Skin changes are more common in secondary HOA

questions.explanation:
Skin changes are more common in primary HOA, not secondary HOA. Hypertrophic osteoarthropathy is a condition characterized by the clubbing of the digits. In 
advanced stages, it is characterized by the periosteal new bone formation and synovial effusion. 
The exact mechanism of its development is unclear. However, platelets are said to have a role in 
the development of HOA via platelet-derived growth factor. There are two types of HOA: 672

questions.question:
Question 5: A middle-aged non-smoker presented with a dry persistent cough and hemoptysis. A CT scan 
showed a mass in the periphery of his right lung. A biopsy was taken, cells showed an acinar 
pattern with mucin formation. The cells were positive for thyroid transcription factor 1 and 
napsin A. What other feature is most likely to be seen in this patient?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario along with the biopsy findings is suggestive of lung adenocarcinoma. It 
is most commonly associated with hypertrophic osteoarthropathy. Adenocarcinomas are mainly seen in the periphery of the lung. They grow in various 
patterns like acinar, lepidic, papillary, micropapillary, and solid with mucin formation. Cells are 
positive for markers like thyroid transcription factor 1 and napsin A. Option C: Hypercalcemia due to ectopic production of PTH-related peptide is seen in squamous 
cell carcinoma. Options B and D: However, SIADH, Cushing’s syndrome, Lambert-Eaton myasthenic 
syndrome are associated with small-cell lung carcinoma.

questions.question:
Question 6: A female patient comes with complaints of unintentional weight loss and right shoulder pain 
for the past 6 months. She reports that the pain radiates to her arm and is not relieved by 
NSAIDs. Chest X-ray is given below. Which nerve roots are likely to be compressed?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario along with the X-ray findings is suggestive of Pancoast syndrome / 
superior sulcus tumor. This affects the C8, T1, and T2 nerve roots. It presents with pain that radiates to the ulnar distribution of the arm, often with the destruction 
of the 1st and 2nd ribs. Patients with the central or endobronchial growth of the primary tumor 
may present with a cough, hemoptysis, wheeze, stridor, dyspnea, or post-obstructive pneumonitis. Regional spread can cause • Tracheal obstruction • Esophageal compression with dysphagia • Recurrent laryngeal paralysis with hoarseness • Phrenic nerve palsy with the elevation of the hemidiaphragm and dyspnea • Sympathetic nerve paralysis with Horner’s syndrome (enophthalmos, ptosis, miosis, and 
anhydrosis) 673

questions.question:
Question 8: What is the treatment of choice in patients with adenocarcinoma of the lung with EGFR 
mutation?
questions.explanation:
Adenocarcinomas with EGFR mutation are exquisitely sensitive to tyrosine kinase inhibitors of 
the EGFR signal pathway such as gefitinib and erlotinib. Option A: Bevacizumab is a monoclonal antibody against VEGF. Option B: Paclitaxel- a taxane, is a plant alkaloid and chemotherapeutic agent. Option C: Imatinib is a tyrosine kinase inhibitor effective in the treatment of CML and GIST.

questions.question:
Question 9: A 55-year-old man presents with persistent cough and hemoptysis. The intern notices that he 
has moon-like facies and purple striae on his abdomen. On evaluation, a chest X-ray revealed 
a mass in his right lung. Which of the following type of lung carcinoma could be the cause of 
this patient's features?
questions.explanation:
In the given clinical scenario the patient has features of Cushing's syndrome, secondary to 
small-cell lung cancer. This occurs due to ectopic ACTH production. It can also seen in pulmonary 
carcinoids. Most effective management is treating underlying SCLC or carcinoid.

questions.question:
Question 10: An elderly man was rushed to the ED with confusion and multiple episodes of vomiting. His 
wife reported that he had increased frequency of urination and constipation for the past 3 669 
Sold by @itachibot days. He is a known case of lung cancer. ECG showed a shortened QT interval. What could be 
the primary cause of his symptoms?

options.b: Syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone secretion
options.c: Ectopic secretion of PTH related peptide

questions.explanation:
The primary cause of his symptoms is ectopic secretion of PTH related peptide. Lung cancers are 
associated with several paraneoplastic syndromes. Squamous cell lung cancer is associated with 
hypercalcemia due to ectopic PTH related peptide. Hypercalcemia may present as vomiting, 674 
Sold by @itachibot abdominal pain, constipation, increased frequency of urination, kidney stones, bone pain and 
shortened QT interval.

questions.question:
Question 11: A 62-year-old woman presents with vomiting, diarrhea, and decreased urine output since 
morning. On the previous day, she received chemotherapy for her stage 4 lung cancer. On 
examination, she is drowsy, HR-110/min and RR-30/min. All of the following biochemical 
findings can be seen in this patient except:
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of tumor lysis syndrome (TLS). It is associated with 
hypocalcemia, not hypercalcemia. TLS is caused by the destruction of a large number of rapidly proliferating neoplastic cells. It is 
usually seen within 1-5 days of receiving chemotherapy. It has also been observed with the 
administration of glucocorticoids, letrozole, tamoxifen, rituximab and gemtuzumab. Rarely, 
spontaneous necrosis of malignancies causes TLS. Clinical features: • Nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, lethargy • Pruritus, renal colicky pain, oliguria • Muscle cramps, carpopedal spasm, tetany Biochemical findings: • Hyperuricemia • Hyperkalemia • Hypocalcemia • Hyperphosphatemia Due to these biochemical changes, there is an increased risk of arrhythmias, acidosis, and acute 
kidney injury.

questions.question: Question 12: Which of the following is not used in the management of patients with tumor lysis syndrome?
questions.explanation:
Sodium bicarbonate is not recommended in the treatment of tumor lysis syndrome (TLS). Urinary alkalinization by sodium bicarbonate decreases the solubility of xanthine, hypoxanthine, 
and calcium phosphate. This potentially increases the risk of intratubular crystallization. Management of TLS includes: • Aggressive hydration • Allopurinol • Rasburicase - recombinant urate oxidase • Febuxostat - non-purine selective xanthine oxidase inhibitor

questions.question:
Question 13: Which of the following patients with non-small lung carcinoma is a suitable candidate to 
undergo a potentially curative surgical resection:

options.a: Transient cessation of neural drive to all respiratory muscles
options.c: Is due to decreased sensitivity to pCO2
options.d: Can be induced by CPAP at high pressure

questions.explanation:
675 
Sold by @itachibot Patients with ipsilateral mediastinal node metastases are suitable candidates for curative 
resection. In patients with NSCLC, the following are contraindications to potentially curative resection: • Extra-thoracic metastases • Vocal cord involvement • Superior vena cava syndrome • Involvement of the main pulmonary artery • Cardiac tamponade • Phrenic nerve paralysis • Malignant pleural effusion • Tumor within 2 cm of the carina • Metastasis to the contralateral lung • Metastases to supraclavicular lymph nodes • Contralateral mediastinal node metastases 676
